title: Tuesday, 20th November 2018

Corporation whose subsidiary, Hovercraft Development Limited (HDL), licensed

BTG's a weird collection of stuff. CroFab, the rattlesnake antidote, is the big earner but has a load of competition incoming.

Dec69 - Skeptic Its international Broker Pump day, and judging by my email bin, some are desperate to prop up any old trash.

Varisolve didn't quite work as planned. The beads thing looks a crowded market.

11:15 am

Then there was the lung coil decompressor thingmy that didn't get FDA approval.

Pharma Can't get worked up about US companies buying UK ones, as the reverse would be allowed. The issue is with companies from countries where foreign takeovers are either not allowed, or blocked politically (China, most of Europe).
Waterloo Allows Woodford to cash in though. Might help save it from selling more illiquid stock
BE11:16am

I'm sure they'll be lots of "selling Britain up the swanee" stuff today, looking back at BTG's interesting heritage, rather than looking closely at what the portfolio actually has.

BE11:17am

Which -- clearly -- is mostly hovercraft IP. Here's Panmure.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Boston Scientific has made a recommended cash offer for BTG. Offering 840p
per share, valuing BTG at $3.3bn. The transaction has been approved by the
boards of both BTG and Boston Scientific. We expect a high probability of
closure of this transaction which is to be effected by a scheme of arrangement.
We move our recommendation to HOLD and target price to 840p. BTG is the
eighth company to be acquired in the UK healthcare sector in the last 18
months, highlighting the generally undervalued UK sector in comparison to the
global healthcare market.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @pharma - when the decisions leave the shores, future value eventually goes with it. You should know this by now!
BE11:17am

In our view the price is a fair, though not generous, valuation for BTG, based on peer
group multiples 2019 EV/EBITDA 14.2x, PE 24.0x compared to BTG 8.9x and 15.2x
respectively (see table on next page). However, we believe the price is significantly
above the share price likely to be achieved by an independent BTG over the next 18
months as concerns over the impact of CroFab competition, which could result in
price pressure and a related fall in profitability, in addition to uncertainty of the ability to deliver on the long term Interventional Medicine (IM) growth rate until data from the EPOCH and STOP-HCC studies are available in 2019, holds back the performance of the shares.

BE11:18am

W e believe a competitive bid is unlikely, given the recommended offer, and the fair
price. BTG’s IM product range fits well into the Boston Scientific interventional
portfolio, with a similar focus on delivery of minimally invasive technologies aided by
improvements in visualisation techniques. Currently Boston Scientific has little
exposure to Interventional Oncology, therefore these products will be entirely
additive, increasing the Boston Scientific IM portfolio. Interventional Vascular
products are mostly complimentary, though in our view there is likely to be a small
overlap in the Roxwood portfolio. The pharmaceuticals products do not fit with
Boston Scientific, though as with the licensing revenue we expect this to be viewed as
a cash cow, as the high margins, and relatively limited requirement for marketing
make these highly profitable divisions.

Flaneur @Kiwi-juice - 'retarded politicians' - I have come to that conclusion too. Across the whole spectrum they appear to be f idiots.@Early Door - black friday? one of the kids wants a keyboard from santa so, for the first time ever, I'll take a peek.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Jefferies.

BE11:18am

Whilst the offer is shy of our street-high 900p Price Target, it appears reasonable in our view when considering that Boston Scientific is likely to focus on the Interventional Oncology franchise and EkoSonic for the treatment of pulmonary embolus, plus coronary catheters. Indeed, excluding our 58p/share NPV for Varithena, our valuation is 840p, with 365p/share for Interventional Oncology, c.115p/share for EkoSonic, and the remainder largely comprising the Specialty Pharma and Royalty Income businesses.

Pharma @1st but you still don't like Brexit...
BE11:19am

(@Flaneur, Kiwi: I'm not wildly keen on the r word. Try to avoid if you want your comment to be preserved for the ages.)

VV75 morning
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Roll up, roll up, UK PLC for sale, will the last one out please switch the lights off!
11:19 am

Oh, and RBC.

BE11:20am

BTG PLC
Waiting game
Our view: We are updating our model for the recent results, which see
profits higher thanks largely due to L&B, lower costs and an FX gain.
However, this 9.0% upgrade to FY19E EPS does not flow through entirely to
the outer years FY20E/21E (-2.1%/+3.1%). We see FY19E as representing
peak earnings for BTG in the medium term should the risks to both Zytiga
and CroFab materialise. Reiterate Underperform.

BE11:21am

Oh, no, wait. That's the sell note they put out at 6am or thereabouts.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Pharma - Contrary to the beliefs of idiots we are party to EU decision making. Unfortunately we don't seem to have the wherewithal to argue our weight in Brussels! And they think it's going to change when we are on our own! Duh!
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Which is unfortunate timing.

BE11:21am

Here's the swift update.

BE11:21am

We see the deal as a good result for BTG shareholders, and think shareholders are likely to view the offer favourably, with the deal
representing an EV of 11.5x CY19E sales for the Interventional Medicine business (likely the key target area for Boston Scientific and the area we see
as having overlap between both companies today). The deal is expected to close post usual shareholder acceptances, but we would note that
Invesco, Novo and Woodford have provided irrevocables equivalent to 32.8% of the issued share capital.

Lemmy It'll get seen through the political lens. Brexiteers: "investment in Britain" etc, Remainers: "UK plc up for sale". But interesting all the same to see incoming M&A despite the events

11:31 am
BE11:31am

The Interims statement provides detail on the breadth of
management's initiatives to mitigate a potential hard Brexit risk. These include planned
investment in H2 of £30m of safety stock (to be held in the UK and Continental Europe)
of faster moving SKUs; working with carriers to ensure cross-border movement of
products; introducing an electronic trading system to simplify cross-border paperwork;
and seeking to source and hold more inventory directly in Europe.

BE11:31am

What a bloody waste.

wayneJ @RW42 - read this - https://newsroom.intel.com/news-releases/supply-update/In particular 'We now expect modest growth in the PC total addressable market (TAM) this year for the first time since 2011, driven by strong demand for gaming as well as commercial systems – a segment where you and your customers trust and count on Intel.'
BE11:31am

Interim results were in line with pre-close guidance: group sales per day (SPD)
growth was 9.8%, and PBT was £100.2m +27%. SPD growth in the first seven weeks
of H2 has moderated to c.7%. We make no changes to our PBT and EPS forecasts.
Despite the strong EPS momentum in the last 12 months the shares have de-rated
from a +12m PE of 25x to 16.4x, which we regard as attractive for 16% EPS CAGR
FY18-21. We retain our BUY and 945p price target.

wayneJ Note the comment on gaming.
11:32 am
BE11:32am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:32am

Another solid set of numbers from ECM and whilst the
economic environment is getting more uncertain, we see further
market share gains driving revenue growth and operational
improvements keeping up the margin progression. Whilst there is
plenty of operational risk yet on the journey to getting the
business to where management (and the market) wants it to be,
we believe the recent share price weakness offers a good entry
point. Therefore, we leave our TP at 710p and move our
recommendation to Add from Hold.

Dec69 - Skeptic I met a gaming chap in New York, makes $600K playing games and people watching....Nuts!
Casper Techmageddon was particularly hard on all the abusers of stock comp. Interesting ponzi dynamic at play there; substantial stock price decline could cause employees to demand ever greater volumes of stock compensation to maintain current income levels (ratchet effect on wages meets today's tech labour shortage), resulting in greater shareholder dilution and further stock price declines. That plus all the momo guys reverse their positions when those turn. Hubspot, Twilio, MongoDB, Zendesk, Salesforce, Proofpoint, Splunk all spanked yesterday

rw42 @wayneJ - Chip seller issues press release wanting to sell chips? Doubt they'll see much sales growth till they've made hardware solutions to all the KPTI related shenanigans..
11:33 am
BE11:33am

The first seven weeks of H2 have seen a slight deceleration in growth to +7% vs.
+10% in H1. This was well-flagged, as the company faces two years of tough comps,
but macro uncertainties are also weighing. EMEA remains the strongest region with
strong share gain, Americas has slowed to +7% (some indirect tariff impact; direct
impact is limited to

BE11:33am

... less than 10% of products within the region), and APAC is below the
average due to Japan and China. The company remains confident but prudently is
making contingency plans, e.g. a £30m inventory build through H2e, and expanding
EU warehouse capacity where possible in case of a 'no deal' Brexit.

BE11:33am

We cut growth forecasts slightly, but raise gross margin and lower SG&A and overall
UBSe EPS for FY19e is unchanged. Electrocomponents has de-rated with other
momentum & cyclicals recently and sits on 15x Mar-20e PE, still in the upper half of the
range through previous cycles of 10-18x.

BE11:39am

Our view: We do not expect a major downturn, but even if there is one the recent sector sell-off has priced in a recession for many names in our coverage group. Relative share price declines have been in many cases worse than past downturns. A number of names are pricing in organic sales declines worse than they have averaged across the last three sector sales downturn phases. On this basis we have a positive bias to our ratings. Our Top Picks are Melrose and Vesuvius and we would also highlight our less consensual Outperform ratings on Rotork and Bodycote.

Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 170.80, up 0.5 (+0.29%), High: 177.00, Low: 168.55, Volume: 7.09m
wayneJ Also there is a perception that Apple is a well oiled logistics machine - its ordering is much more erratic than eg Nokia's ever was.
11:39 am
Bodycote PLC (BOY:LSE): Last: 742.00, up 2.5 (+0.34%), High: 749.50, Low: 719.00, Volume: 177.73k
BE11:40am

Lead indicators have rolled over and weakness is clear in certain markets (e.g. Automotive). However, it is less clear that this a widespread downturn. If we count the 2014-16 oil & gas related industrial weakness, then a 2-year upcycle would appear very short. Even if we go further back, the 2% organic sales CAGR seen by the sector overall since 2011 has hardly been a raucous upcycle and as such any softening is unlikely to be as dramatic as 2009 (sector organic sales -12%), rather it is more likely to resemble 2004 or 2015 (both -4%).

Dec69 - Skeptic @Bones, AG Barr, my estimate is its a bet again declining market share, price up significantly and outlook flat (see what I did there.)
red @rw42talking tech in general. besides i thought gaming is what folks do coz they cant get laid.
wayneJ Also a lot of the day to day is not run by Apple but by Foxconn et al.
BE11:40am

The recent peak to trough share price fall for the group at an average of 28% compares to an average of the past six major sell-offs of 47% decline. We have rebounded slightly to an average down 24% from peak. On a market relative basis the recent peak to trough falls were on average 19% (now 15% post some recent recovery) versus the average sell-off of the past 6 downturns at 24%, i.e. you could say we have been within 5% of pricing in a recession. Melrose, Smiths, IMI, Rotork, and Weir all have troughs this year close to the average of their past six sell-downs.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

(That "within 5% of pricing in a recession" idea seems a bit of a reach, but w'ev.)

BE11:41am

So:

BE11:41am

Top Picks / Outperforms: Our positive view on sector valuation means that we have an average upside of 22% to our price targets. Top Picks are Melrose and Vesuvius. We also have Outperform ratings on Bodycote, Coats, RHI Magnesita, Rotork and Weir. Our EPS forecasts are most above consensus on Vesuvius and RHI Magnesita. On a rating basis we would note that Rotork and Bodycote stand out as names that consensus is relatively less positive on.  Underperform ratings: Given the high level of upside we are looking for across the group, our Underperform ratings are not necessarily significant downside statements. However, Spirax-Sarco and Smiths Group have both priced in less weakness than our coverage group in the recent sell- down. Spirax is limited by a very high valuation and Smiths has rebounded recently on break-up news, but continues to struggle for operational momentum.

11:41 am
Spirax-Sarco Engineering PLC (SPX:LSE): Last: 6,110, down 485 (-7.35%), High: 6,480, Low: 6,060, Volume: 69.85k
wayneJ The other behaviour I think it is important to recognise / suspect is that there has been a lot of ordering to get product out of China before sanctions / tariffs hit. And the Chinese supply chain is now letting component inventories fall as they cannot be sure that they will get renewed orders in Jan (depending on the orange one's mood)

11:48 am
BE11:48am

...The group also reports that the recent Concept Life Sciences acquisition is trading below expectations (although this is more than offset by strength elsewhere in the Materials Analysis division). More important than any of this, however, is the earlier than expected indication from new CEO Andrew Heath of where he intends to take the group. He says all the the key things that we wanted to hear: Spectris will focus on improving margins and increasing operating leverage; it will drop the complex and risky shared services programs it will undertake a strategic review to look at portfolio construction and capital allocation,
and will do what it takes to increase shareholder value. With Spectris's set of high gross margin businesses, and modest current valuations, we think that there is much that can be achieved with an approach of this kind, and that the message from management will be well received: now it is all about details and execution.

wayneJ I have a fantastic idea to reduce delivery costs for Royal Mail parcels and other courier companies..... ring the customer if they do not reply to the doorbell (especially if your staff cannot be trusted to find the doorbell).

wayneJ KIM 1 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KIM-1 (nothing to do with North Korea)
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Management highlighted (I) strong organic growth +8% (N.America +6%, EU +2%,
Asia +16%, ROW +7%), (ii) Phase 1 of Project Uplift on track, (iii) Commencing a
cost reduction programme that should drive operational efficiencies and margins,
(iv) Group margins below peers with Spectris spending more than desired, (v)
Concept Life Sciences performance below expectations with management
working on remedial actions, (vi) China has seen growth strength across the
board from all businesses, (vii) End market strength in Pharma, Autos, Semis and
Academic, (viii) £55m trade flow exposure (£47m from US into China; £8m from
China into US) —for 2019 estimate £4-8m (direct and indirect impact) after the
mitigation offsets, (ix) will look at the portfolio, and how the business optimises
its assets and how management deploys capital, (x) the cost saving program will
target the gap between gross margin and EBITA margin and will include moving
some labour to lower cost areas, some site rationalization and some structural &
process change, (xi) on Auto trends – Spectris is more R&D focused than
production focused and is benefiting from more new platforms in development
(EV/hybrids/ battery testing / autonomous driving) and is seeing strength in R&D,
(xii) still seeing strong semis growth, (xiii) margins were at 18.5% margins earlier in
the decade. Management wants to do better than that and longer term are
targeting 20%+.

Grouchmonkey Any comment on Scapa, please?
undefined

BE11:57am

NAM ORG has accelerated from +6.6% (ex Easter) in Q3 to +9.6% in
Q4 giving FY18 +7.8% (Citi +7.4%) reflecting the phasing of sports events and
strong underlying growth. Europe saw its ORG improve from +2.0% ex Easter to
+4.2% in Q4 giving FY18 at +2.1% (Citi +1.6%) driven by stronger net new business
in UK. ROW saw ORG dip from +2.7% ex Easter in Q3 to +1.7% in Q4 giving FY18
at +2.9% (Citi +3.1%) as the Wheatstone contract moved into production.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

We expect little change to consensus. Company expectations for
FY2019 are “positive” and it is guiding to ORG in the middle of its 4-6% range. We
assume FY19E ORG of +5.5%, supported by continued strong growth in NAM and
an unwind of the Defence, Offshore & Remote drag in ROW. Combined with +6bps
EBIT margin growth, we expect this to drive adj EBIT up +8% to £1,874m and EPS
+10% to 84.6p.

BE11:57am

Compass has a deserved reputation as a quality growth
company and we think its defensive growth characteristics and non-UK exposure
will continue to appeal to investors. We also note the robust FCF (4.5% FY19E FCF
yield pre growth capex), and strong growth outlook (10% 3yr EPS CAGR). Based
on our FY19E forecasts Compass trades at c.19x PE and c.12x EV/EBITDA vs
peers on 15x and 9x respectively.

Positives:

BE11:58am

(1) Strong Q4 NA exit rate at 9.4%, “broad-based growth”, 60% from
first time outsourcing and small competitors, bodes well for FY19 guidance of
7%+, albeit the company said Q4 was ~7.5% ex some non-recurring factors. (2)
9.1% FY sales growth from new business wins the strongest since 2010, despite
the business being 60% larger. (3) Strong pushback on concerns over US labour
costs (“relentless focus on efficiencies”, “US contracts allow us to pass on costs
faster than in Europe, and food cost inflation lower in US”, saw 2%-pt drop in
staff turnover), Foodbuy contract loss (“dynamic environment, fractionally
disappointed” but have replaced lost volume, and compliance just as important
as scale) and Delivery (“no dramatic negatives but not complacent”). (4) Expects
to use FCF and disposal proceeds either to make more acquisitions or do more
buybacks; will update at H1 in May.

wayneJ What did the German electronics retailer (Metro?) become - did it rename itself?
11:58 am
BE11:59am

Negatives:

BE11:59am

(1) Disposals confirmed at ~5% of sales at a group average margin of
7%, despite initial disposals being only a ~2% margin, implies future disposals at
above average margin, and ~5% off 2020 consensus EBIT. (2) UK getting more
challenging on both a LfL volume and cost perspective, and although signals on
Continental Europe are better the company guides to a dull FY19 performance in
Europe (2-2.5% organic sales vs Q4 18 +4%, margins +5-10bps so only a partial
rebound from -50bps). (3) RoW outlook weaker, Compass now guides to c.2%
organic sales growth with flat margin in FY19, weaker than FY18’s 2.9% and its
prior margin guidance of +20bps, though expects commodity drag to end by H2.
(4) Capex guidance increased from 3.0-3.5% to “around 3.5%” in FY19 (“up to 3.5%”
in the presentation), mix of capex changing to intangible spend (+28% in FY18),
amortisation charge rose by much less (company noted 8 yr average contract
length on contracts with capex vs 5 for the group).

BE12:11pm

Peel Hunt:

BE12:11pm

Polypipe published a trading statement this morning covering the 4 months to end October 2018, which will be well received by the stock market. Group LfL sales growth was +10.2% over the period with both divisions performing well (Residential Systems +11.5%, Commercial & Infrastructure +8.6%). This is partly explained by catch up demand following weather disruptions in March/April but we think this growth also represents continued market share gains and product substitution, which is central to our investment thesis. Management also reported rising operating margins in the second half of the year (although this may be due to the consolidation of the higher margin Manthorpe business) and re-iterated its FY2018F guidance.
